reasoning: [Specific Program Not Verified] Paper mentions 'Vietnam Bank for Social Policies (VBSP) Microfinance Program' but search could not confirm this as graduation program: Perplexity search result: The Vietnam Bank for Social Policies (VBSP) Microfinance Program is a large-scale government-operated microfinance initiative primarily offering subsidized loans (micro-credit) to low-income and poor populations. Authoritative sources clearly state that the main intervention is the provision of preferential credit (loans) and not direct cash transfers, stipends, or unconditional monetary grants[1][4][5][6][7][8]. There is no evidence from official evaluations, impact assessments, or academic literature that the program systematically distributes productive assets (such as livestock, equipment, or tools) to clients as a core component. Most sources focus on credit access, the role of loans in financing microenterprises, and how these loans can increase incomes and reduce poverty, but do not reference grants or asset transfers. Graduation programs are defined by a multi-component approach that combines sequenced cash, assets, training, savings, and mentoring; there is no evidence that VBSP systematically implements this comprehensive, bundled approach as pioneered by BRAC and evaluated by J-PAL/IPA. VBSP is a traditional microcredit provider, not a graduation program. | Graduation: NO, Cash: NO, Assets: NO | Confidence: HIGH | Sources: https://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/54154/1/MPRA_paper_54154.pdf, https://documents1.worldbank.org/curated/en/920381614318030116/pdf/Review-of-the-Vietnam-Bank-for-Social%20Policies.pdf, https://www.emerald.com/jed/article/24/1/18/220603/The-impact-of-the-Vietnam-Bank-for-Social-Policies
verified_program_name: Vietnam Bank for Social Policies (VBSP) Microfinance Program
